Subject: Drop In Center (Prevention Point Philadelphia)
Object: The Drop In Center strives to be free of judgment, allowing people of all backgrounds to come in and relax. The Drop In Center is in many ways the gateway through which participants are connected to the many services provided by PPP. This program provides:- Case management- HIV/HCV testing and counseling- Mail services- Legal clinic- Medical services- CRAFT (links participants to addiction treatment)- Specialized surveys - MealsThe Drop In Center is open five days a week and provides daily respite for clients from outside weather.

Subject: Drop In Center (Prevention Point Philadelphia)

Subject: Overnight Services (Horizon House)
Object: The Horizon House Navigation Center in West Philadelphia offers a variety of support services to homeless adults all year round. Here, people have a safe haven to meet their basic needs. The center is open 7 p.m. to 6 a.m. and is available on a drop-in basis.  Services include:- Temporary shelter- Food- Shower- Clean clothing- Laundry facilities- Medical and psychiatric assessments- Case managementExtended daytime hours are available two days/week for medical and psychiatric assessments and referral services. Case management services are offered to link individuals with appropriate housing, benefits, medical care and treatment services.For more information, please call at 215-386-3838, ext. 12603

Subject: Overnight Services (Horizon House)

Subject: Emergency Safe Havens (Women Against Abuse)
Object: Women Against Abuse’s two 24-hour emergency safe havens provide free services to survivors of all gender identities and their children who are victims of domestic violence. This program provides:- Up to 90 days of shelter- Case management- Individual & group counseling- Three meals a day- Children's health assessments- Emergency relocation funds (as available)- Adult education & job readiness referrals- After school & summer school programs- On-site child careIf you need emergency housing because of a domestic violence situation, please call the toll-free 24-hour Philadelphia Domestic Violence Hotline (866-723-3014).

Subject: Crisis Care Services (Covenant House)
Object:
Covenant House's Crisis Care Services are short-term programs where a homeless child's most pressing, urgent needs are met immediately. There is no requirement that a young person be referred through an official channel – they can come anytime, day or night.

This program provides:

- Shelter
- Hot meal
- Emergency medical care
- Showers

This program also provides:

- Mental health care
- Legal assistance 

During the intake process, kids share their stories with trained staff so their immediate needs can be identified and then a plan is created for the best way to support them.

Subject: Crisis Care Services (Covenant House)

Subject: Emergency Shelter (HELP USA Pennsylvania)
Object: HELP USA is there for those who find themselves suddenly homeless, and they provide them with safe, temporary shelter and the support they need to get back on their feet. They believe in a different kind of homeless shelter – one that is respectful, supportive, and treats each resident as a unique individual.This program provides:- Temporary shelter- Day care and afterschool care- Physical and mental healthcare- Navigating the system- Help find work

Subject: Emergency Shelter (Families Forward)
Object: Families Forward Philadelphia offers an emergency family shelter, for families in need, that has 65 individual rooms. While obtaining housing is their top priority, they also encourage saving money – working with families to dedicate funds to rent, furnishings and day-to-day living expenses once they leave the shelter.This program provides:- A warm, safe environment- Nutritious meals- Case managementAdditionally throughout the day, workshops are available to prepare families for independent living, including parenting classes, life skills development, computer classes, money management classes, and much more.

Station House Intake Center Services (SELF, Inc.)
Object: Centralized Homeless Intake Services includes an assessment of eligibility and service needs of persons and families presenting for placement into emergency housing. If eligible, persons and families are placed in appropriate emergency housing, boarding homes, or other alternative housing. Services include:- Temporary shelter- Ongoing case management services- Assistance with obtaining transitional and/or permanent housing- Supportive housing for special populations- An optional savings program which allows households to save a part of their income for future housing expensesMental health assessments and referrals to drug/alcohol treatment, health services, children and youth services, legal services and veteran’s services, etc., are provided as needed to clients of the program.- Connecting Services to other community resources- ScreeningIf you are currently experiencing homelessness, please call us during business hours. You must go through central intake for an initial assessment of your housing needs before placement into the homeless housing system.

Subject: Youth Services (Covenant House Pennsylvania)
Object: Covenant House Pennsylvania offers shelter and supportive services to young people experiencing homelessness. They aim to help homeless young people become healthy, happy, responsible, productive, and ultimately independent adults.This program provides:- A safe, secure environment- Immediate and transitional housing- Rapid rehousing- Meals and food- Case Management- Spiritual Support- Counseling- Physical health, mental health, and drug and alcohol services- Saving and budgeting- Continuing education- Support for LGBTQ individuals- Job readinessThe Crisis Center is open 24 hours per day, seven days per week. There are no shelter fees; however, those staying at the shelter must deposit 75% of their income during their stay. All money is returned upon leaving the shelter. Covenant House is a drug and weapon-free program.

Subject: Youth Services (Covenant House Pennsylvania)
Object: This program covers residents of the following counties: Philadelphia County, PA.

Subject: Residential Maternity Shelter (Mother's Home)
Object: Mothers' Home provides a Residential Maternity Shelter and supportive services for pregnant women who are homeless or in crisis over the age of 18 who do not have other children in their care.This program provides: - Temporary housingWomen in the shelter have access to:- Life skills training- Parenting classes- Job readiness training- Counseling services- Pre and postnatal health education- Childbirth and development classes- Housing search assistance- Educational classes on budgeting, legal, and nutrition- Initial personal and baby supplies- Peer supportWomen may continue to reside in our Residential Maternity Shelter for up to six months after giving birth.

Homeless Veterans Initiative (Disabled American Veterans)
Object:
The DAV Homeless Veterans Initiative, supported by DAV’s Charitable Service Trust and Columbia Trust, promotes the development of supportive housing and necessary services to assist homeless veterans in becoming productive, self-sufficient members of society. Our goal is to establish a partnership between the DAV and Federal, state, county and local governments to develop programs to assist homeless veterans in becoming self-sufficient.

Service:

-counsel individuals on the many VA benefits for which they may be entitled

If you or someone you know is a homeless veteran in need of assistance, please contact us.

Subject: Homeless Veterans Initiative (Disabled American Veterans)
Object: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

Financial Assistance for Military Families (American Red Cross)
Object: The American Red Cross works in partnership with military aid societies to provide quality, reliable financial assistance to eligible applicants 24/7/365 in times of hardship.This program provides: - Financial assistance for emergency needsAssistance can include funds for emergency travel, burial of a loved one, emergency food and shelter, etc. Red Cross helps to facilitate the application process, the military aid society determines eligibility and the specific financial assistance package that is offered.You can submit a request online or call the American Red Cross Hero Care Center.  When calliing, be sure to have the following information ready to provide the representative:- Legal name- Rank or rating- Social Security number- Date of birth- Branch of service (Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, Coast Guard)- Military unit address- Information about the deployed unit and home base unit (for deployed service members only)
